DOC.HEAD: Leader Of Failed Homeland Coup Gets 18-Year Prison Term
DOC.TEXT: A soldier who led a failed coup attempt in one of South Africa's nominally independent black homelands has been sentenced to 18 years in prison for high treason. Warrant Officer Timothy Phiri was the last of 142 soldiers to be sentenced for their roles in a February 1988 coup attempt in Bophuthatswana, one of four tribal homelands designated independent by South Africa but not recognized abroad. The other defendants, convicted last month of treason or terrorism, were sentenced Monday and Tuesday to prison terms ranging from 2 to 10 years. The coup was crushed by South African commandos, who freed homeland president Lucas Mangope from captivity at a soccer stadium and arrested the rebels, all members of the homeland army. Bophuthatswana Supreme Court Justice M.W. Friedman said Phiri was ``a danger to society'' who had allowed Mangope to be ill-treated during the coup attempt and had ordered his rebels to fire on the homes of homeland Cabinet ministers.
